Svabhavakripana, a Brahman whose very name, "A born miser," bespoke his nature, possessed little in the world save for a small measure of surplus rice. This precious grain, saved from his meager alms, he carefully stored in an old, unglazed earthen pot. He hung this pot from a peg on the wall of his simple dwelling, directly above his sleeping mat, so that it might always be within his watchful gaze. To him, this humble pot, brimming with its starchy treasure, represented not merely a meal, but the kernel of future prosperity, the bedrock upon which his grandest dreams would be built.

Summary:
Svabhavakripana, a miserly Brahman, hoards a small amount of rice in a pot, imagining it will grow into vast wealth and power. His fantasies of becoming a merchant king and controlling his family lead him to impulsively kick the pot, shattering it and losing his rice. The tale warns against unrealistic ambitions and neglecting the present, as his greed and overreach destroy his meager possessions. The moral underscores the folly of building castles in the sky without grounding in reality.

Lost completely in this vivid daydream, Svabhavakripana forgot his present reality. His imaginary son's defiance, his beautiful daughter's (his wife's) perceived indulgence, and his own rising anger felt utterly real. His foot connected not with an imaginary foe, but with the very real earthen pot hanging above his head, shattering it instantly. The pot splintered into a thousand pieces, and the precious surplus rice rained down upon his face and mat, mixing with the dust of his shattered dreams.
